ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about French literature, French colonialism, and French history. I also improved my active and passive skills in French.
I gained so much knowledge of all the works that we studied in this course, including the back stories of the authors, a bit of each works influence on the world, and the history of the work.
I learned a lot about French literature and also significantly improved my writing skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the use of a structuring theme was very helpful and provided a good balance of breadth and depth. The readings were well chosen and interesting. I also liked the organization of writing assignments into two longer papers and a number of short responses.

I think that the prompted discussion questions provided for each of the works worked super well because that way the discussion was more guided and we were able to discuss a lot of topics that we wouldnt have otherwise thought to talk about.  The individual presentations were also nice because they allowed us to practice our public speaking and research skills.
I enjoyed the readings very much and also how the course was taught. Not much to improve on here.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: By and large, I thought this course made good use of Zoom and Canvas. The breakout rooms were effective, and though Madame Pinzka initially shared her screen to type a term instead of using the chat feature, she started using chat more often as the semester progressed.
I think everything went very smoothly.
Virtual discussions are always difficult but I really did enjoy when we were in breakout rooms because it allowed me to engage with my peers on a deeper level.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the French language and in literature written in the French language.
Yes! I feel as though Im now very knowledgeable in the field of french literature.
I would definitely recommend this course. It provides a great introduction to many different French texts.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also used breakout rooms and were encouraged to discuss in smaller two- or three-person groups outside of class.
Smaller group meetings on zoom outside of class to further practice of french conversational and speaking skills.

extras.title:
FREN 170 01
        Intro Study of French Lit
